paragraphs.title: What
paragraphs.p:
A block-diagonal form matrix
\inv{P}AP = \begin{bmatrix} U_1 \\ \amp U_2 \\ \amp \amp \ddots \\ \amp \amp \amp U_\ell \end{bmatrix} , where each block U corresponds to a specific eigenvalue \lambda of A, has size equal to the algebraic multiplicity of \lambda, and is in scalar-triangular form with \lambda down the diagonal.

paragraphs.title: When

aside.title: Note
aside.p: If A is a complex matrix (or, at least, regarded as a complex matrix), then this condition is always true.

paragraphs.title: How
paragraphs.p: Follow the scalar-triangular form procedure () with \lambda = \lambda_1, but stop when you have m_1 linearly independent vectors. Use these vectors as the first columns of P. Repeat with \lambda = \lambda_2 to get the next m_2 columns of P. And so on.

aside.title: Recall
aside.p: Each subcollection of vectors from applying the scalar-triangular form procedure for a specific eigenvalue \lambda_j will form a basis for the generalized eigenspace G_{\lambda_j}(A).

paragraphs.title: Result
paragraphs.p: Each block U_j will be as in the described result for .
